abstract_summ: We extract shocks to time-varying credit uncertainty and decompose it into two parts: the first captures the"pure"effect of a shock to the second moment; the second captures total effects of uncertainty including effects on the first moment.We feed the estimated shocks into a flexible price real business cycle model with a collateral constraint and show that when the collateral constraint binds, an uncertainty shock about credit access is recessionary leading to a simultaneous decline in consumption, investment, and output.At the same time, OEU is related to increases in stock prices – unlike aggregate uncertainty, which has the opposite effect.First, the relationship between investor attention and Islamic stock returns exhibits time-variation and nonlinearity as investor attention significantly impacts the dynamics of Islamic returns, but its sign and effect vary per quantile.Second, we enumerate the mechanisms that researchers have postulated to link uncertainty shocks and business cycles.
